48328 February 2009
Field Note
Rural Water Supply Series
An Introduction to Self Supply: Putting the User First Incremental improvements and private investment in rural water supply
Self Supply encourages the incremental improvement of household and community supply through user investment in water treatment, supply construction and up-grading, including small rainwater harvesting and groundwater systems. It is a concept which complements conventional rural water supply funded by government, enabling self-help improvement of supplies where no protected supply is available, or where consumers feel they can support higher levels of service than are presently provided by the public sector.  Background rural areas. Donordependentstep Larger contractors and simplified maintenance What is Self Supply?i
Self Supply is the improvement to household or community water supply through user investment in water treatment, supply construction and up-grading, and rainwater harvesting. It is based on incremental improvements in steps which are easily replicable, with Local artisans technologies affordable to users. This self-help approach is complementary Enduseraffordablesteps iFor more details see the RSWN Self Supply Site www.rswn.ch
2  An Introduction to Self Supply Putting the User First

Originally subsidised to a small (<20 percent) extent, the overall cost of $200- Figure 5. Sealed family well with new rope pump, Oromia Region 300 was chiefly borne by well-owners. By 2006 over 120,000 family wells had been up-graded, serving more than 1.5 million people at minimal subsidy by donors or the state ($3-5 per head). Many new families have dug wells on seeing the standards and convenience which could be achieved, or on finding that wells were possible in areas with no previous history of them, almost doubling the number in use. Thus Self Supply is not limited to any particular technology, but only by the resources of, and technical support to investors.
Household water supply ­ Mali
In Mali approximately 5 million people take their water from traditional wells they have constructed themselves, either through their own labour or by paying someone else. Over 200,000 predominantly family wells (see Figure 7) are in use in rural and peri-urban areas, but with little private sector or government support. Over 90 percent are within 100 metres of the houses using them, and these people use almost twice as much water as those
Sutton) over 500m from their supply9. The

7  Supply can contribute to MDGs
Box 3. MDG Contribution, Self Supply and the Eight Goals
Goal Self Supply Contribution
1 Eradication of Homestead ­based technologies tend to be used most intensively for multiple uses (enhanced land and water Poverty and Hunger productivity, rural livelihoods and gender equity)13. In South East Asia irrigation reduced poverty across all study systems14 and water supply improvements provided the opportunity to create income through micro­enterprises, as well as time released from water collection being converted into income earned15.
In Mali a survey in two regions showed that 85 percent of water supplies with domestic and productive use were privately owned family wells9.
Families with rope pumps generate an average of $225 more per annum of income (ie about 50 percent above average), in Nicaragua16.
2 Universal A 12 percent increase in Tanzanian school attendance was found when water is available within fifteen minutes Primary Education instead of being more than an hour away17.
In Mali 95 percent of family wells were within fifteen minutes of the home, but only a third of communal wells9.
3 Gender Household-level decision making generally favours greater input from female members. Men are more prepared to collect water from sources nearer the house, especially if access and/or site hygiene is improved18.
Water provision close to the house offers women in particular the opportunity for productive use where their mobility is socially constrained13, and greater women's empowerment through changing gender relations within the household15.
4 Child Mortality Among children under five years in developing countries, diarrhoeal disease accounts for 21 percent of all deaths19.
"Children with homes more than 500 m from their water supply had much higher rates of diarrhoea compared with children from houses with their own supply"20. Fewtrell's recent systematic review21 of high quality studies of household water treatment at the point of use and improved storage demonstrated a 34 percent reduction in diarrhoea.
5 Maternal Reduced burden in water carrying during pregnancy, and possibly better Mortality post-natal hygiene can reduce complications.
6 HIV/AIDS, Easier availability of water for hygiene/hand washing which reduce opportunistic Malaria/TB transmission in adults and children23. diseases and respiratory infections for HIV/AIDS and others22. HH Water treatment successfully prevented cholera
7 Environmental Sustainable development sustainability Self Supply offers sustainable technologies and management systems, spreads abstraction of groundwater among diffuse points and reduces concentration of livestock around water points. It may lead to increased abstraction but this tends to be naturally limited by its effect on the water table.
Sustainable access to safe drinking water Access can be generally at household level, or near neighbour, where water is available within 15m of surface or as rainwater harvesting. Safety is ensured by household water treatment, which is now being widely promoted.
8 Global Capacity building Partnership for In co-operation with the private sector, making available the benefits of new technologies, and re-inforcing Development decentralised capacity to respond to demands even with minimum resources.
Youth job prospects Growth in demand for well-diggers, masons, blacksmiths and carpenters expands rural job opportunities. In Sierra Leone in association with the newly-formed well-digger union, ex-combatant youth have been offered job creation and credit systems to develop new marketable skills in water supply.
8  An Introduction to Self Supply Putting the User First

About the author Author: Dr Sally Sutton
Peer reviewers: Zahra Ayadi and Jerome Rihouey (WSP-Africa), Egbert Schroten Dr. Sally Sutton is the RWSN Self Supply Flagship Theme Coordinator. and Boniface Aleobua (OWAS/AfDB), She has more than 30 years experience in rural water supply, starting Erich Bauhmann (RWSN)
as a practical hydro-geologist and moving increasingly into planning and Prepared under the guidance of the evaluation, systems and policy development for improved sustainability. RSWN secretariat A major interest is in helping to bridge the gaps which often exist between end-users and policy makers/sector professionals, so that consumers have Contacts: Dr Sally Sutton
informed access to a wider range of options which reflect their concerns sally@ssutton.fsbusiness.co.uk and Kerstin Danert and values. kerstin.danert@skat.ch

doc.repnme: An introduction to self supply : putting the user first incremental improvements and private investment in rural water supply
doc.abstracts: The overall goal of Rural Water Supply Network (RWSN) is to lower costs, and improve sustainability of rural water supplies in Sub-Saharan Africa to help achieve the Millennium development goals (MDGs). This goal is further divided into four inter-linking themes, known as flagships with the following aims within Sub-Saharan Africa: 1) self supply - private investment and household initiative are incorporated into national and international strategies for rural water supply improvement; 2) cost-effective boreholes (CEB) - policies are adopted and practices are followed which bring about cost-effective borehole provision; 3) sustainable water supplies (SWS) - rural households obtain highly valued community water supply services which they are capable of sustaining indefinitely; and 4) handpump technologies (HT) - good quality production of handpumps, is ensured along with appropriate selection, procurement and simplified maintenance.
